Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Listen actively, attending to tone, intonation and body language
Elaboration: Demonstrating appropriate body language while listening; for example, using body orientation, eye contact, facial expressions and gestures such as nodding or shaking their head

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Listen actively, attending to tone, intonation and body language
Elaboration: Recognising how tone and intonation distinguish a statement from a question, and use this in their own utterances

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify some points of information in short spoken texts, with teacher support
Elaboration: Identifying learnt vocabulary and sentence structures in familiar spoken texts

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify some points of information in short spoken texts, with teacher support
Elaboration: Pointing to parts of pictures that are mentioned in a text or conversation

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify some points of information in short spoken texts, with teacher support
Elaboration: Using questions to help identify relevant items of information; for example, Teacher: ‘What colour was it?’ Student: ‘It was blue.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify some points of information in short spoken texts, with teacher support
Elaboration: Responding to simple, familiar instructions or questions, for example to ‘Open the book to this page.’, ‘Write your name.’ and ‘How old are you?’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in simple conversations and classroom routines, relying on other speakers to scaffold, interpret, clarify or elabourate
Elaboration: Indicating agreement or non-agreement through body language or gestures (e.g. nodding or shaking their head) or using formulaic speech (e.g. ‘I agree.’ and ‘I don’t think so.’)

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in simple conversations and classroom routines, relying on other speakers to scaffold, interpret, clarify or elabourate
Elaboration: Using some culturally appropriate conventions such as ‘excuse me’, ‘please’ and ‘thank you’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in simple conversations and classroom routines, relying on other speakers to scaffold, interpret, clarify or elabourate
Elaboration: Using learnt formulas to make simple requests and express needs, thoughts and opinions, for example ‘What’s the time?’, ‘Oh, no!’, ‘Can I eat lunch?’ and ‘I want …’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in simple conversations and classroom routines, relying on other speakers to scaffold, interpret, clarify or elabourate
Elaboration: Borrowing key topic words and structures from a question; for example, Teacher: ‘What is your hobby?’ Student: ‘My hobby is …’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in simple conversations and classroom routines, relying on other speakers to scaffold, interpret, clarify or elabourate
Elaboration: Understanding common classroom action verbs such as ‘sit’, and in ‘stand up’ and ‘pack up’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in simple conversations and classroom routines, relying on other speakers to scaffold, interpret, clarify or elabourate
Elaboration: Following simple task instructions by relying on key words or phrases in context, for example when asked ‘Open the window.’, ‘Please bring me your work.’ and ‘Use the coloured pencils.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in simple conversations and classroom routines, relying on other speakers to scaffold, interpret, clarify or elabourate
Elaboration: Providing short responses to familiar questions, for example when asked ‘How old are you?’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Reproduce or role-play short scenarios or exchanges
Elaboration: Exchanging and responding to feedback about aspects of speech with group members when rehearsing or performing role-plays, for example for phrasing, fluency, intonation, volume and pace

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Construct short utterances, with contextual support
Elaboration: Combining learnt vocabulary to describe objects and ideas, for example ‘very hot’ and ‘beautiful picture’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Construct short utterances, with contextual support
Elaboration: Using a variety of familiar words in the correct order to make simple utterances

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use simple conjunctions
Elaboration: Using common vocabulary and short formulaic expressions to communicate intention, for example ‘Please shut door.’ and ‘Turn on the light.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use simple conjunctions
Elaboration: Pointing, miming or gesturing to supplement speech

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a range of familiar basic verb forms accurately
Elaboration: Matching simple verb tense to time words, for example in ‘Yesterday we went …’, ‘Now we can eat lunch.’ and ‘Tomorrow we will go …’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a range of familiar basic verb forms accurately
Elaboration: Maintaining consistent tense when describing events in the past, present and future, for example ‘I walked to his house and we played games.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a range of familiar basic verb forms accurately
Elaboration: Understanding and attempting to use some basic expressions of modality such as ‘want to’, ‘have to’ and ‘should’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a range of familiar basic verb forms accurately
Elaboration: Using ‘no’ or ‘not’ with verbs, adjectives and nouns to express negative forms, for example ‘Not play.’, ‘I no sad.’ and ‘Me no …’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a narrow range of descriptive language words and phrases
Elaboration: Using a range of adjectives to express affect (such as ‘frightened’ and ‘surprised’), judgement (such as ‘naughty’ and ‘brave’) and appreciation (such as ‘interesting’)

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a narrow range of descriptive language words and phrases
Elaboration: Forming simple noun groups that combine one or 2 adjectives with a noun, for example ‘hot day’ and ‘scary old house’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a narrow range of descriptive language words and phrases
Elaboration: Formulating short adverbial phrases, for example ‘on my bike’, ‘with his brother’ and ‘every week’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a variety of key words in a range of familiar and common situations
Elaboration: Connecting a small number of words from a common topic or theme, for example ‘bike’, ‘wheel’, ‘tyre’ and ‘handlebars’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a variety of key words in a range of familiar and common situations
Elaboration: Recognising familiar and learnt vocabulary in short spoken texts

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a variety of key words in a range of familiar and common situations
Elaboration: Using common synonyms (such as ‘hot’ and ‘warm’) and antonyms (such as ‘fast’ and ‘slow’) to communicate a variety of meanings

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use comprehensible pronunciation for a range of high-frequency words learnt in class
Elaboration: Developing comprehensible pronunciation through imitation and rehearsal

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use comprehensible pronunciation for a range of high-frequency words learnt in class
Elaboration: Using accurate pronunciation for a range of high-frequency words used in classroom instructions, texts and interactions

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use comprehensible pronunciation for a range of high-frequency words learnt in class
Elaboration: Substituting middle sounds in spoken words to make new words (e.g. changing ‘pin’ to ‘pen’) and substituting final sounds in spoken words (e.g. substituting the ‘t’ in ‘pet’ with ‘g’ to form a new word, ‘peg’)

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use comprehensible pronunciation for a range of high-frequency words learnt in class
Elaboration: Identifying and repeating rhyming words using blends of phonemes (the smallest units of sound in words), for example for ‘share’ and ‘chair’, ‘mind’ and ‘find’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use comprehensible pronunciation for a range of high-frequency words learnt in class
Elaboration: Identifying and producing phonemes in blends or clusters at the beginning and end of syllables, for example in ‘sh-ip’ and ‘di-sh’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use comprehensible pronunciation for a range of high-frequency words learnt in class
Elaboration: Blending 2 or 3 phonemes together to make syllables, for example in ‘b-oo-k’ and ‘sh-ee-t’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use sentence stress, intonation and other paralinguistic (non-verbal) features to support communication
Elaboration: Attending to and using intonation and tone to distinguish between questions, instructions and statements

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use sentence stress, intonation and other paralinguistic (non-verbal) features to support communication
Elaboration: Recognising and imitating features of sounds and intonation in the speech of the teacher and peers, and in video or audio clips

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use sentence stress, intonation and other paralinguistic (non-verbal) features to support communication
Elaboration: Expressing emotions such as happiness and anger through intonation

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use sentence stress, intonation and other paralinguistic (non-verbal) features to support communication
Elaboration: Using appropriate paralinguistic (non-verbal) features to support meaning; for example, making eye contact and using facial expressions, gestures and posture

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify differences between aspects of spoken English and other languages
Elaboration: Recognising the sounds and words of English in interactions

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify differences between aspects of spoken English and other languages
Elaboration: Asking the teacher or peers about appropriate behaviour in certain situations, for example ‘Should I use eye contact?’ and ‘Is it okay to shake hands?’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify differences between aspects of spoken English and other languages
Elaboration: Exploring the nature of social interactions with familiar people and in known settings; for example, learning how to greet a peer, a classroom teacher and the principal and comparing it to a home language

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Ask for repetition or clarification to confirm understanding of spoken communication and ask for help
Elaboration: Assessing engagement and understanding of a listener, including checking for attentive posture or confused facial expressions, noticing from the listener’s body language that something has not been understood and then repeating words or phrases

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Ask for repetition or clarification to confirm understanding of spoken communication and ask for help
Elaboration: Self-correcting pronunciation or rephrasing sentences in simple ways when a listener indicates they have not understood

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Ask for repetition or clarification to confirm understanding of spoken communication and ask for help
Elaboration: Clarifying instructions before acting, by recasting key words (e.g. ‘Open them?’ and ‘These pencils?’) or by indicating the objects

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Ask for repetition or clarification to confirm understanding of spoken communication and ask for help
Elaboration: Asking for repetition or clarification from a speaker (such as using ‘Please repeat.’ and ‘What means …?’), referring to the speaker’s key words; for example, Teacher: ‘Please get your dictionary.’ Student: ‘What is dictionary?’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Ask for repetition or clarification to confirm understanding of spoken communication and ask for help
Elaboration: Checking understanding of classroom English with other home language speakers

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Draw on a range of home language resources to enhance learning when listening and speaking
Elaboration: Asking home language peers to explain an idea in a home language and asking for a translation in English

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Draw on a range of home language resources to enhance learning when listening and speaking
Elaboration: Formulating questions in English and a home language to clarify classroom instructions or new ideas and vocabulary

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Listen and speak appropriately during small-group interactions
Elaboration: Displaying appropriate listening behaviours; for example, having attentive posture and using appropriate facial expressions and gestures

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Listen and speak appropriately during small-group interactions
Elaboration: Taking turns attending to the expressions of other speakers, and incorporating cues such as questions or key words into their own responses

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Listen and speak appropriately during small-group interactions
Elaboration: Formulating questions in English and a home language to clarify classroom instructions or new ideas and vocabulary

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use key words to understand the main idea in a range of simple short texts based on predictable language structures and vocabulary
Elaboration: Identifying the main topic of a short paragraph; for example, saying ‘This is about dogs.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use key words to understand the main idea in a range of simple short texts based on predictable language structures and vocabulary
Elaboration: Identifying the main characters and events in a short narrative when given a prompt, for example when asked ‘In this paragraph, can you find the name of the main character?’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Extract some information from simple short texts, with teacher support
Elaboration: Following instructions, for example to plant a seed in a pot or draw parts of a story

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Extract some information from simple short texts, with teacher support
Elaboration: Following instructions related to labelled items or locations, for example when asked ‘Take out your laptop.’ and ‘Place your printed work in the “finished” basket.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Extract some information from a narrow range of images, with teacher support
Elaboration: Locating city or country names on a simple map

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Extract some information from a narrow range of images, with teacher support
Elaboration: Matching phrases and sentences from a text to images or diagrams that show the same ideas

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Extract some information from a narrow range of images, with teacher support
Elaboration: Identifying the topic and structure of a text based on its layout and visual appearance; for example, using headings or illustrations

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Extract some information from a narrow range of images, with teacher support
Elaboration: Using organisational features to navigate a text, including multimodal and interactive texts; for example, using titles and headings in a print text or hyperlinks and navigational items in a digital text

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Make simple predictions or inferences about a text
Elaboration: Using pictures to predict the events in a narrative, or images, diagrams, graphs and tables to predict the content of an information text

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Make simple predictions or inferences about a text
Elaboration: Suggesting what might happen next in a narrative with a familiar setting or characters

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Make simple predictions or inferences about a text
Elaboration: Answering simple questions based on images, for example in response to ‘How is the character feeling?’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Compare text types and identify differences between them
Elaboration: Comparing and describing a variety of text types such as recount, report, narrative, slide show, webpage and podcast

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Compare text types and identify differences between them
Elaboration: Answering questions about text purpose and organisation, for example when asked ‘Which text tells us how to do something?’ and ‘Which texts use headings?’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Compare text types and identify differences between them
Elaboration: Suggesting an audience for a text, for example ‘This book is written for children.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Understand the purpose and basic organisational features of simple text types
Elaboration: Using language, layout or topic to distinguish between information and fictional texts

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Understand the purpose and basic organisational features of simple text types
Elaboration: Finding information in a text, for example when asked ‘Use the contents list to find the section about lions.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Understand the sequence of key words, phrases or ideas in a familiar text
Elaboration: Creating a simple storyboard to show the sequence of ideas from a text

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Understand the sequence of key words, phrases or ideas in a familiar text
Elaboration: Filling in missing items in a sequence of key words, phrases or sections from a text

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Read sentences that use basic subject, verb and object patterns, where content and vocabulary are familiar
Elaboration: Ordering words jumbled in a sentence to create a grammatical and logical sentence

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Read sentences that use basic subject, verb and object patterns, where content and vocabulary are familiar
Elaboration: Answering literal questions about familiar texts; for example, Teacher: ‘What did the dog eat?’ Student: ‘The dog ate the bone.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify simple present and past tense verbs
Elaboration: Locating verbs in a text and distinguishing between their tenses

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify simple present and past tense verbs
Elaboration: Matching pairs of simple present and past tense verbs such as ‘go’ and ‘went’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify simple present and past tense verbs
Elaboration: Using familiar irregular verbs such as ‘swim’ and ‘swam’ within their text

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Read some familiar words and phrases
Elaboration: Using previous knowledge to read familiar sight words and phrases in unfamiliar texts, for example for words from a high-frequency word list and familiar sentence starters such as ‘Once upon a time …’ and ‘Today is …’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Read some familiar words and phrases
Elaboration: Attempting to read new forms of familiar words, and self-correcting using knowledge of base words and common morphemes (meaningful units within words), for example for ‘walk’, ‘walked’ and ‘walks’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Read some familiar words and phrases
Elaboration: Using initial letters and common letter patterns to decode unfamiliar words; for example, identifying rhyming words

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Read some familiar words and phrases
Elaboration: Recognising some common prefixes and suffixes such as ‘un-’ and ‘-er’ and how they change the meaning of words

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Read some familiar words and phrases
Elaboration: Recognising familiar words and collocations such as ‘big bad wolf’ in different contexts

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify common syllables and patterns within words
Elaboration: Naming letters and giving their sounds when spelling or sounding out unfamiliar words

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify common syllables and patterns within words
Elaboration: Recognising sounds that can be produced by different letters such as the ‘s’ sound in ‘sat’ and ‘cent’, and using this knowledge to decode words when reading

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify common syllables and patterns within words
Elaboration: Understanding that a syllable must contain a vowel sound

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify common syllables and patterns within words
Elaboration: Recognising beginning, middle and final sounds in words

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify common syllables and patterns within words
Elaboration: Recognising one- and 2-syllable words that are part of spoken vocabulary, using knowledge of short vowels, common long vowels, consonant blends and digraphs

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify common syllables and patterns within words
Elaboration: Reading aloud words that are familiar or contain familiar letter patterns with some accuracy and confidence

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Understand the function of spaces, capital letters and full stops
Elaboration: Pausing at a full stop when reading

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Understand the function of spaces, capital letters and full stops
Elaboration: Recognising when words require capital letters, for example for names and at the beginning of sentences

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Understand the function of spaces, capital letters and full stops
Elaboration: Explaining why a word starts with a capital letter; for example, saying it is a name or it is the first word in a sentence

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise key differences between texts in English and in other languages
Elaboration: Suggesting ways of beginning or ending a story in different languages, for example ‘Instead of “Once upon a time”, in my language we say …’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise key differences between texts in English and in other languages
Elaboration: Engaging with texts about ideas and events from different places, times and cultures

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise key differences between texts in English and in other languages
Elaboration: Identifying differences in cultural features of texts in English and in a home language

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Select suitable books to read, with teacher support
Elaboration: Choosing a variety of texts with different settings and themes

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Select suitable books to read, with teacher support
Elaboration: Skimming part of a book before selecting, to check for familiar English content, images, size and amount of print, and layout

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Select suitable books to read, with teacher support
Elaboration: Comparing books with those previously read to predict the suitability of topic, language, length and structure

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Select suitable books to read, with teacher support
Elaboration: Re-reading familiar texts to increase accuracy and fluency, and to enhance understanding

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Select suitable books to read, with teacher support
Elaboration: Reading texts in English and/or a home language to caregivers or siblings

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Draw on a range of home language resources to enhance learning when reading and viewing
Elaboration: Writing notes in a home language about meaning and pronunciation when encountering unfamiliar words in texts

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Draw on a range of home language resources to enhance learning when reading and viewing
Elaboration: Using a bilingual dictionary to find translations of unfamiliar words, and noting these in a home language and English

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Draw on a range of home language resources to enhance learning when reading and viewing
Elaboration: Asking home language peers to explain an idea in a home language and asking for a translation in English

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Draw on a range of home language resources to enhance learning when reading and viewing
Elaboration: Asking home language peers or the teacher for the English translation and spelling of a home language word

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in teacher-led shared reading activities, relating aspects of imaginative texts to their own experience
Elaboration: Naming and describing characters from a text

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in teacher-led shared reading activities, relating aspects of imaginative texts to their own experience
Elaboration: Giving a simple personal response to a text, for example ‘I enjoyed it.’ or ‘I learnt about …’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in teacher-led shared reading activities, relating aspects of imaginative texts to their own experience
Elaboration: Describing the feelings of a character in simple terms, based on print text and accompanying images

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in teacher-led shared reading activities, relating aspects of imaginative texts to their own experience
Elaboration: Recounting a similar experience to that of a character (e.g. ‘That happened to me once, when …’) and describing similarities and differences between a text and their own experience (e.g. identifying events that are familiar or new)

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in teacher-led shared reading activities, relating aspects of imaginative texts to their own experience
Elaboration: Joining group discussions by listening to other students and giving brief, relevant responses to questions

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in teacher-led shared reading activities, relating aspects of imaginative texts to their own experience
Elaboration: Self-correcting pronunciation, or repeating a sentence with corrected pronunciation and improved fluency, when reading aloud

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write ‘real world’ personal texts, with teacher support
Elaboration: Making a list of items to take on an excursion, using the names of familiar objects

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write ‘real world’ personal texts, with teacher support
Elaboration: Writing a letter introducing themselves, using some formulaic expressions such as ‘Dear …’ and ‘I live in …’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write ‘real world’ personal texts, with teacher support
Elaboration: Writing a simple story to share with the class, based on listening to a story told at home

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write simple information texts for a variety of classroom purposes, with teacher support
Elaboration: Writing simple information texts to give information or instructions, or to keep records (e.g. keeping a digital class journal)

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write simple information texts for a variety of classroom purposes, with teacher support
Elaboration: Making a list of class expectations and routines

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write simple information texts for a variety of classroom purposes, with teacher support
Elaboration: Using examples of digital ‘listicles’ as models to create their own versions

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write simple imaginative texts modelled on familiar forms and repetitive patterns, with teacher support
Elaboration: Following the structure of modelled texts; for example, writing in first person, as a sequence of events or a reflection in a diary

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write simple imaginative texts modelled on familiar forms and repetitive patterns, with teacher support
Elaboration: Writing imaginative texts adapted from or in response to classroom texts; for example, writing a story with an alternative setting or ending

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write simple imaginative texts modelled on familiar forms and repetitive patterns, with teacher support
Elaboration: Using digital tools to produce simple imaginative texts

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use images to support simple narrative or recount sentences, with teacher support
Elaboration: Creating illustrations or diagrams to accompany sentences in a narrative or recount

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use images to support simple narrative or recount sentences, with teacher support
Elaboration: Labelling simple diagrams or pictures using familiar words

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use images to support simple narrative or recount sentences, with teacher support
Elaboration: Writing simple phrases as captions or explanations for drawings

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use images to support simple narrative or recount sentences, with teacher support
Elaboration: Using digital storyboarding to create a simple story map to show the events and characters in a narrative

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Organise some subject matter and attempt to write paragraphs and topic sentences, using modelled forms and repetitive patterns
Elaboration: Using templates or graphic organisers or following model texts for organisational structure; for example, including an introduction, body paragraphs and conclusion

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Organise some subject matter and attempt to write paragraphs and topic sentences, using modelled forms and repetitive patterns
Elaboration: Grouping sentences about the same topic into simple paragraphs, for example ‘Frogs are green. Frogs have big eyes. They eat insects.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Organise some subject matter and attempt to write paragraphs and topic sentences, using modelled forms and repetitive patterns
Elaboration: Using key words to write a simple topic sentence at the beginning of most paragraphs

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Organise some subject matter and attempt to write paragraphs and topic sentences, using modelled forms and repetitive patterns
Elaboration: Copying topic sentences or parts of sentences to support idea generation and to structure writing

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Organise some subject matter and attempt to write paragraphs and topic sentences, using modelled forms and repetitive patterns
Elaboration: Separating ideas in texts by leaving a line or writing a heading

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Organise some subject matter and attempt to write paragraphs and topic sentences, using modelled forms and repetitive patterns
Elaboration: Using tools to format a digital text; for example, making headings using a larger font, formatting text and placing images near relevant text

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Sequence ideas using short sentences or statements
Elaboration: Writing a series of short statements in time sequence, for example ‘I eat breakfast. I go to school. I read a book.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Sequence ideas using short sentences or statements
Elaboration: Using formulaic time markers such as ‘On Monday …’, ‘First …’, ‘After that …’ and ‘Last …’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Sequence ideas using short sentences or statements
Elaboration: Using formulaic sentence beginnings throughout a text (e.g. ‘On the weekend, I … And then I … Then I …’) and using simple pronoun references to avoid repeating the subject in consecutive sentences (e.g. ‘Emma came to school early. She felt very tired.’ and ‘Yesterday the class went … We went …’)

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Sequence ideas using short sentences or statements
Elaboration: Constructing basic compound sentences with a narrow range of coordinating conjunctions such as ‘and’, ‘but’ and ‘so’, for example ‘I caught a bus and then walked.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Sequence ideas using short sentences or statements
Elaboration: Constructing basic complex sentences using some common subordinating conjunctions such as ‘because’, ‘when’ and ‘after’, for example ‘After we finished dinner, Mum wanted to play a game.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use common verb forms correctly
Elaboration: Using common simple past tense forms with the suffix ‘-ed’ consistently, although overgeneralising rules for some less common irregular past tense verbs (e.g. writing ‘catched’, ‘freezed’ and ‘waked’)

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use common verb forms correctly
Elaboration: Using common irregular past tense verbs such as ‘went’, ‘said’ and ‘bought’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use common verb forms correctly
Elaboration: Expressing simple negative constructions accurately, for example ‘I do not like …’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a narrow range of simple descriptive phrases
Elaboration: Building simple noun phrases using adjectives, for example ‘the blue car’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a narrow range of simple descriptive phrases
Elaboration: Using a narrow range of adverbs and phrases to add circumstance, for example ‘The car goes fast.’ and ‘I sat on a chair.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a narrow range of simple descriptive phrases
Elaboration: Using simple comparative adjectives in basic sentences with varying accuracy, for example ‘My brother bigger than me.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Incorporate learnt vocabulary into writing
Elaboration: Matching words to definitions or labelling diagrams

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Incorporate learnt vocabulary into writing
Elaboration: Referring to classroom charts and a personal vocabulary list for key vocabulary

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Incorporate learnt vocabulary into writing
Elaboration: Repeating words for emphasis or impact, for example ‘many, many people’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Spell common words encountered in class accurately
Elaboration: Spelling high-frequency words such as ‘the’, ‘and’, ‘is’ and ‘it’ using knowledge of phoneme–grapheme correspondence

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Spell common words encountered in class accurately
Elaboration: Using sound or visual features to spell unfamiliar words such as ‘every’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Spell common words encountered in class accurately
Elaboration: Referring to classroom charts and a personal vocabulary list to check or confirm spelling

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Spell common words encountered in class accurately
Elaboration: Breaking unfamiliar words into morphemes (meaningful units within words) or syllables using a picture dictionary or bilingual dictionary to search for a word in English

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Spell common words encountered in class accurately
